title: Equality, sports, and Title IX - Erin Buzuvis and Kristine Newhall

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the change in the way girls were treated in sports?

options.label: A
options.text: Title IX was passed to reduce the number of girls playing sports.

options.label: B
options.text: Title IX protected girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities.

options.label: C
options.text: Title IX encouraged girls to participate in sports more than boys.

options.label: D
options.text: Title IX required schools to provide equal opportunities for girls.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of college athletes were women in 1972?
According to Title IX, what is the purpose of the three tests (proportionality, progress, and satisfied interests) for schools to demonstrate fairness in opportunities for girls?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce the number of girls playing sports.

options.label: B
options.text: To make sports more equal by giving girls the same opportunities as boys.

options.label: C
options.text: To give schools three options, or tests, to demonstrate fairness in opportunities for girls.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the number of boys playing sports.

multiple-choice.question: What does the test of proportionality require schools to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities by adding new sports for girls.

options.label: B
options.text: To give girls the same percentage of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls in the student body.

options.label: C
options.text: To regularly ask female students what sports they are interested in.

options.label: D
options.text: To take into consideration the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located.

multiple-choice.question: What is another important part of Title IX, besides requiring equality in opportunities for girls?

options.label: A
options.text: To give boys more athletic opportunities than girls.

options.label: B
options.text: To make sure girls have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces, and competitive facilities, as well as medical services.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the number of girls playing sports.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the number of boys playing sports.

multiple-choice.question: What does the test of progress require schools to make up for the days when girls had fewer opportunities?

options.label: A
options.text: To give girls the same percentage of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls in the student body.

options.label: B
options.text: To regularly ask female students what sports they are interested in.

options.label: C
options.text: To add new sports for girls on a regular basis.

options.label: D
options.text: To take into consideration the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located.

multiple-choice.question: What should schools do if the best time to play basketball is on Friday nights because that's when most parents and fans can come?

options.label: A
options.text: The boys' team and the girls' team should take turns playing on Friday night.

options.label: B
options.text: The boys' team should play on Friday nights, and the girls' team should play on another day.

options.label: C
options.text: The girls' team should play on Friday nights, and the boys' team should play on another day.

options.label: D
options.text: The boys' team should play on Friday nights, and the girls' team should play on the weekends.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the Office of Civil Rights in ensuring schools comply with Title IX?

options.label: A
options.text: A school administrator who is responsible for making sure there is fairness in sports.

options.label: B
options.text: A parent who is responsible for making sure there is fairness in sports.

options.label: C
options.text: A government agency that makes sure schools comply with Title IX.

options.label: D
options.text: A teacher who is responsible for making sure there is fairness in sports.

multiple-choice.question: What should you do if you think there might be inequality in your school?

options.label: B
options.text: Approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights.

options.label: C
options.text: Talk to your friends about it.

options.label: D
options.text: Write a letter to the school board.

multiple-choice.question: Why is equality important for everyone, both on the field and off?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's a requirement by the government.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's a requirement by the school.

options.label: C
options.text: Because equality is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's a requirement by the parents.

multiple-choice.question: What were the original percentages of girls and women in sports before Title IX was passed?

options.label: A
options.text: Girls made up 15% of college athletes and 7% of high school athletes.

options.label: B
options.text: Girls made up 25% of college athletes and 15% of high school athletes.

options.label: C
options.text: Girls made up 20% of college athletes and 10% of high school athletes.

options.label: D
options.text: Girls made up 30% of college athletes and 20% of high school athletes.

multiple-choice.question: What does Title IX require schools to do when it comes to athletic opportunities and facilities?

options.label: A
options.text: Schools must provide separate facilities for boys and girls.

options.label: B
options.text: Schools must provide equal facilities for boys and girls in terms of athletic opportunities and facilities.

options.label: C
options.text: Schools must provide more facilities for boys than for girls.

options.label: D
options.text: Schools must provide facilities for only boys.

multiple-choice.question: What does the test of satisfied interests require schools to do?

options.label: A
options.text: To give girls the same percentage of athletic opportunities as the percentage of girls in the student body.

options.label: B
options.text: To regularly ask female students what sports they are interested in.

options.label: C
options.text: To add new sports for girls on a regular basis.

options.label: D
options.text: To take into consideration the popularity of certain sports in the area where the school is located.

multiple-choice.question: Why should you be an advocate for equality in your school?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's your responsibility as a student.

options.label: C
options.text: Because equality is important for everyone, both on the field and off.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's required by the school administration.

multiple-choice.question: What should you do if you witness or experience inequality in your school?

options.label: B
options.text: Approach a school administrator, a parent, or the Office of Civil Rights.

options.label: C
options.text: Talk to your friends about it.

options.label: D
options.text: Write a letter to the school board.

title: The happy secret to better work - Shawn Achor

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason behind the negative information presented on the news?

options.label: A
options.text: The news media has a bias towards negative reporting.

options.label: B
options.text: The lens through which our brain views the world shapes our reality.

options.label: C
options.text: The external world is predictive of our happiness levels.

options.label: D
options.text: Our brain is wired to focus on the negative.

options.label: B
options.text: It is based on external factors rather than internal ones.

options.label: C
options.text: It is scientifically broken and backwards because it pushes happiness over the cognitive horizon.

options.label: D
options.text: It only applies to certain individuals.

What is the main idea behind the concept of positive psychology?

options.label: A
options.text: To study what is merely average and remain average.

options.label: B
options.text: To delete the positive outliers and focus on the average.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the positive outliers and learn from them to move the entire average up.

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: It doesn't handle the case of 1 person in the room.

options.text: To handle the case of 0 people in the room.

options.label: B
options.text: To handle the case of 1 person in the room.

options.label: C
options.text: To handle the case of multiple people in the room.

options.text: To initialize n to a negative number.

options.text: It initializes n to a negative number.

options.label: D
options.text: It doesn't handle the case of an odd number of people.

options.label: D

title: Leaders and followers: what tango teaches

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the terms "leader" and "follower" in the context of Tango dancing?

options.label: A
options.text: They are specific to men and women.

options.label: C
options.text: They are determined by the music.

options.label: D
options.text: They are decided by the dance instructor.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a misconception about the follower's role in Tango dancing?

options.label: A
options.text: The follower is always passive and does not take responsibility for their movements.

options.label: B
options.text: The follower is always creative and improvises freely.

options.label: C
options.text: The follower is only responsible for their own movements.

options.label: D
options.text: The follower has no influence on the dance.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following types of following is demonstrated as "weak" in the transcript?
What is the follower's responsibility when the leader loses focus or balance during a dance?

options.label: A
options.text: To let the dance fall apart.

options.label: B
options.text: To take over and lead the dance.

options.label: C
options.text: To stabilize the leader and keep the dance moving along.

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the follower-leader relationship in Tango dancing?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a conversation in which they help each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of demonstrating different types of following in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the importance of the leader's role.

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the different styles of following.

options.label: C
options.text: To illustrate the various approaches to following.

options.label: D
options.text: To highlight the creativity of the follower.

multiple-choice.question: How does the follower's approach influence the creative potential of the leader in Tango dancing?

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the leader's creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the leader feel weak.

multiple-choice.question: According to Isaac, what was it like when Sha was being the "showing off" follower?

options.label: B
options.text: It felt like he was dancing alone.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a follower who fights against their leader during a dance?
According to the transcript, what is the nature of the follower-leader relationship in Tango dancing?

options.label: C
options.text: It is a complementary and never hierarchical relationship.
